newsitem.title: UK: Investors, analysts hail BT, MCI, Telefonica deal.
newsitem.headline: Investors, analysts hail BT, MCI, Telefonica deal.

text.p: British Telecommunications Plc said on Friday it had formed a global telecoms alliance with U.S. group MCI Communications Corp and Spain's Telefonica de Espana SA.
Analysts said the partners would benefit from the pact which gave them a formidable position in the Latin American market. The companies said that market could be worth more than $60 billion by 2000.
BT said it would take a two percent stake in Telefonica, while the Spanish company would buy a one percent holding in BT. The crossholdings would cost around 280 million pounds ($457.2 million) each.
Telefonica said in the joint statement that it was also taking steps to leave its Unisource alliance with U.S. group AT&T Corp and three other European telecom companies.
The companies said the alliance would "reshape the global telecommunications landscape" and enable them to combine resources and exploit opportunities across the Americas and Europe.
London investors hailed the deal, sending BT shares higher in a weakening market. BT hit an intraday high of 450 pence, up 7 1/2 pence.
Analysts said the terms of the alliance were favourable and welcomed Telefonica's move to abandon its link with AT&T.

"This is good news although it has been expected in the market and it looks like Telefonica has paid 440p for BT share, which should lend some support," said Jim McCafferty, analyst at ABN AMRO Hoare Govett in London.

The deal was widely expected. Portugal Telecom earlier this week signed up to join Concert -- the company formed by a merger of BT and MCI -- and the Portuguese company had let slip in its own announcement a reference to Telefonica joining up with MCI.
Under the terms of the deal, Telefonica International SA (TISA) and MCI will create a pan-American joint venture, with each partner holding 50 percent.
MCI and Telefonica would also set up a marketing arrangement to target the Hispanic community in the U.S., currently estimated at more than 28 million people, the companies said.
